informal_statement: The square root of $t$ is greater than $2$ and less than $3.5$. How many integer values of $t$ satisfy this condition? Show that it is 8.
informal_proof: We have: $2 < \sqrt{t} < \frac{7}{2}$ so squaring the inequality (which we can do because all the terms in it are positive) gives us  $4 < t <\frac{49}{4}=12.25$.  Therefore, $t$ is an integer between 5 and 12 inclusive, which leaves us with $8$ possible integer values of $t$.
formal_statement:
theorem mathd_algebra_224:
  "card { n :: nat. sqrt n < 7 / 2 \<and> 2 < sqrt n} = 8"
formal_code:
(*
  Authors: Wenda Li
*)

theory mathd_algebra_224 
  imports Complex_Main "HOL-Computational_Algebra.Computational_Algebra"
  "HOL-Number_Theory.Number_Theory"
begin

theorem mathd_algebra_224:
  "card { n :: nat. sqrt n < 7 / 2 \<and> 2 < sqrt n} = 8"
  sorry

end
